title: Selenous acid - why Ka2 is smaller than Ka1

content.question:
Step 1: <math> <semantics> <mrow> <msub> <mtext>H</mtext> <mn>2</mn> </msub> <msub> <mrow> <mtext>SeO</mtext></mrow> <mn>3</mn> </msub> <mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>⇄</mo><msub> <mrow> <mtext>HSeO</mtext></mrow> <mn>3</mn> </msub> <msup> <mrow></mrow> <mo>−</mo> </msup> <mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>+</mo><msup> <mtext>H</mtext> <mo>+</mo> </msup> <mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><msub> <mi>K</mi> <mrow> <msub> <mi>a</mi> <mn>1</mn> </msub> </mrow> </msub> <mo>=</mo><mn>2.1</mn><mo>×</mo><msup> <mrow> <mn>10</mn></mrow> <mrow> <mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow> </msup> </mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaahGart1ev3aaatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLn hiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbd9wDYLwzYbItLDharqqtubsr 4rNCHbGeaGqiFC0pg9uqGrpepeea0dXdHaVhbbe9u8qqaqFr0xc9pk 0xj9qqaqFj0dh9qq=xfr=JarFfpeea0=as0=fs0di9uqFr0=vr0=vr 0db8meaabaqaciGacaGaaeqabaWaaeaaeaaakeaaqaaaaaaaaaWdbi aabIeadaWgaaWcbaGaaGOmaaqabaGccaqGtbGaaeyzaiaab+eapaWa aSbaaSqaa8qacaaIZaaapaqabaGcpeGaaiikaiaadggacaWGXbGaai ykaiablsCiakaabIeacaqGtbGaaeyzaiaab+eapaWaaSbaaSqaa8qa caaIZaaapaqabaGcdaahaaWcbeqaaiabgkHiTaaak8qacaGGOaGaam yyaiaadghacaGGPaGaey4kaSIaaeisamaaCaaaleqabaGaey4kaSca aOGaaiikaiaadggacaWGXbGaaiykaiaaywW7caaMf8Uaam4samaaBa aaleaacaWGHbWaaSbaaWqaaiaaigdaaeqaaaWcbeaakiabg2da9iaa ikdacaGGUaGaaGymaiabgEna0kaaigdacaaIWaWaaWbaaSqabeaacq GHsislcaaIZaaaaaaa@6134@ </annotation> </semantics> </math> 

Step 2: <math> <semantics> <mrow> <msub> <mrow> <mtext>HSeO</mtext></mrow> <mn>3</mn> </msub> <msup> <mrow></mrow> <mo>−</mo> </msup> <mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>⇄</mo><msub> <mrow> <mtext>SeO</mtext></mrow> <mn>3</mn> </msub> <msup> <mrow></mrow> <mrow> <mn>2</mn><mo>−</mo></mrow> </msup> <mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>+</mo><msup> <mtext>H</mtext> <mo>+</mo> </msup> <mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><msub> <mi>K</mi> <mrow> <msub> <mi>a</mi> <mn>2</mn> </msub> </mrow> </msub> <mo>=</mo><mn>5.3</mn><mo>×</mo><msup> <mrow> <mn>10</mn></mrow> <mrow> <mo>−</mo><mn>9</mn></mrow> </msup> </mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaahGart1ev3aaatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLn hiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbd9wDYLwzYbItLDharqqtubsr 4rNCHbGeaGqiFC0pg9uqGrpepeea0dXdHaVhbbe9u8qqaqFr0xc9pk 0xj9qqaqFj0dh9qq=xfr=JarFfpeea0=as0=fs0di9uqFr0=vr0=vr 0db8meaabaqaciGacaGaaeqabaWaaeaaeaaakeaaqaaaaaaaaaWdbi aabIeacaqGtbGaaeyzaiaab+eapaWaaSbaaSqaa8qacaaIZaaapaqa baGcdaahaaWcbeqaaiabgkHiTaaak8qacaGGOaGaamyyaiaadghaca GGPaGaeSiXHaOaae4uaiaabwgacaqGpbWdamaaBaaaleaapeGaaG4m aaWdaeqaaOWaaWbaaSqabeaacaaIYaGaeyOeI0caaOWdbiaacIcaca WGHbGaamyCaiaacMcacqGHRaWkcaqGibWaaWbaaSqabeaacqGHRaWk aaGccaGGOaGaamyyaiaadghacaGGPaGaaGzbVlaaywW7caWGlbWaaS baaSqaaiaadggadaWgaaadbaGaaGOmaaqabaaaleqaaOGaeyypa0Ja aGynaiaac6cacaaIZaGaey41aqRaaGymaiaaicdadaahaaWcbeqaai abgkHiTiaaiMdaaaaaaa@6163@ </annotation> </semantics> </math>

The step-wise dissociation of selenous acid, H2SeO3(aq), is represented by the equations above. Which of the following best helps explain why the value of <math aria-label=""> <msub> <mi>K</mi> <mrow> <msub> <mi>a</mi> <mn>2</mn> </msub> </mrow> </msub> </math> is so much smaller than the value of <math aria-label="undefined"> <mrow> <msub> <mi>K</mi> <mrow> <msub> <mi>a</mi> <mn>1</mn> </msub> </mrow> </msub> </mrow> </math> ?

choices.label: The Se atom in H2SeO3(aq) is in a higher oxidation state than the Se atom in HSeO3-(aq) .
Water is more attracted to HSeO3-(aq) ions than to SeO32- ions, which drives the step 2 equilibrium toward the reactant.
The HSeO3-(aq) ions produced in step 1 are asymmetrical, but the SeO32- ions produced in step 2 are symmetrical.
Removing the first H+ from H2SeO3(aq) requires less energy than removing the second H+, because the second H+ is removed from a negatively charged species.

content.answer: Removing the first H+ from H2SeO3(aq) requires less energy than removing the second H+, because the second H+ is removed from a negatively charged species.

topic.text: 8.6: Molecular Structure of Acids and Bases

skill.text: 6.C: Support a claim with evidence from representations or models at the particulate level, such as the structure of atoms and/or molecules.
